This is not necessarily true. It is true random chance plays a big role. For example the scientists doing controlled studies on positive feedback could be self-selecting themselves ideologically for these types of studies to prove a confirmation bias they already had and they may by chance be the type of scientists who fudge the data for a desired outcome. Negative feedback worked for centuries and you can read biography after biography to see that it is possible that people doing these studies are interested in the confirmation bias that they desire positive feedback environments. But if all humans desire positive feedback, then why would negative feedback ever evolve in societies and military cultures throughout the world independently? Because the science is not yet solid on this. Negative feedback does indeed work better, that experience matters, you can see this with chess players, constant positive feedback and no improvements, constant negative feedbacks and suddenly their skills go up. So how does the science explain this ? That's the thing, we don't know if certain scientists are just doing things for ideological reasons. We should scientifically test that bias. From a philosophical perspective, reality IS NEGATIVE, therefore, it makes sense that feedback must be negative, because reality is not positive when things are going wrong. So the idea that you can just use positive feedback or no feedback at all and see skill improvements in students is absurd and any scientist arguing that has to get their head checked. Testosterone levels aside, obviously motivation plays a big role in sports, but it doesn't improve skill.

The psychologist Daniel Kahneman, winner of the 2002 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences, pointed out that regression to the mean might explain why rebukes can seem to improve performance, while praise seems to backfire.[13]

I had the most satisfying Eureka experience of my career while attempting to teach flight instructors that praise is more effective than punishment for promoting skill-learning. When I had finished my enthusiastic speech, one of the most seasoned instructors in the audience raised his hand and made his own short speech, which began by conceding that positive reinforcement might be good for the birds, but went on to deny that it was optimal for flight cadets. He said, "On many occasions I have praised flight cadets for clean execution of some aerobatic maneuver, and in general when they try it again, they do worse. On the other hand, I have often screamed at cadets for bad execution, and in general they do better the next time. So please don't tell us that reinforcement works and punishment does not, because the opposite is the case." This was a joyous moment, in which I understood an important truth about the world: because we tend to reward others when they do well and punish them when they do badly, and because there is regression to the mean, it is part of the human condition that we are statistically punished for rewarding others and rewarded for punishing them. I immediately arranged a demonstration in which each participant tossed two coins at a target behind his back, without any feedback. We measured the distances from the target and could see that those who had done best the first time had mostly deteriorated on their second try, and vice versa. But I knew that this demonstration would not undo the effects of lifelong exposure to a perverse contingency.

In a maths test where the mean is say 60%, focus on the students who scored say 80.
This group will consist of people who overperformed and also people who underperformed.
But by the nature of the normal distribution, there will be more overperformers than underperformers because there is a higher density of people to the left of 80 than to the right.
So next test, you would expect more people going down than going up.
THAT is regression to the mean.

geez will this never end? The gamblers "fallacy" is not a fallacy at all, it's a mis-statement of the strong law of large numbers.

It is true that if you flip a coin a certain number of times, a coin with two possible outcomes A and A-, heads & tails, A and not-A, that the probability of A increases with each instance of not A. Because in the long run the probability of each is 50 50 but having performed the experiment X times, you now have only N-X repetitions to perform so that the probabilities ARE affected by previous outcomes. The whole question is just how much they are affected. There is a whole segment of game-show history based on this where a similar question was asked of Marilyn vos Savant who quickly and elegantly said that given 3 doors with a prize behind ONE of them, choosing one door (but not opening it) and then opening one of the other 2 doors to show that the prize was NOT behind it changed the odds that the prize was behind the THIRD door from 1 in 3 to 2 in 1.

People went absolutely apeshit over this. The universaly-accepted answer was that the odds were the same for the prize being behind one of the two unopened doors. But the probability calculation is pretty simple to show that this is not the case, and it is an excellent example of consumer bias. People simply want to believe that the door they first chose was the right door, the winning door, and if nothing else, just as good as the unopened, unchosen door. Not a door with far worse odds of winning than the 3rd door. But it is simple. When none of the doors have been opened, or even selected, the odds are equal of each having the prize. With one door chosen but remaining closed, the odds are unchanged. When the 2nd door is opened and shown to be false, the odds of the 3rd door having the prize become the same as the odds of the 2 un-chosen doors having the prize vs the chosen door, or 2:1. Again, a simple exercise in probability is just too difficult for most people to understand not to mention to accept, and I'm not talking about average people, this answer upset a lot of scientists, even physicists if you can imagine that. They just cannot wrap their minds around the simple fact that given 3 equal chances, choosing 1 and being shown a 2nd made the 3rd twice as likely as the first.

It is just that counter-intuitive.

As long as the number of coin-flips is LIMITED, then the same phenomenon occurs.
Just as in blackjack, this is the reason why card-counting is outlawed at legitimate blackjack tables, the reason why high-stakes tables will mix together several decks in the shoe.

The odds only remain even when the number of coin-flips is unlimited. Just as in any card game, the odds of any one hand coming up depends on the number of possible opportunities for that hand vs all possible hands, which depends on how many decks are in the dealers' shoe. Because the strong law of large numbers only holds when the test in question is repeated a large # of times. When the test is only repeated a few times, then the general probabilities (and inferred statistics) no longer hold, and as such the strong law of large numbers does not hold true.

Doesn't mean that flipping heads 3x in a row means that the next flip will be tails, again, no strict regression to the mean.
But tails is much more likely than heads if you consider only 6 flips. You can calculate it precisely by calculating the odds that out of 6 flips the first 3 will be tails and the 4th heads vs all the other possible combinations (or permutations) of 6 coin-flips...out of 4 coin flips the odds of guessing them all correctly is 1 in 16, but now you know 3 out of the 4 so the odds are now 1 in 2...again, ignoring the strong law of large numbers, and assuming that both remaining outcomes are EQUALLY LIKELY.

!!!!! But !!!!

they only become independent, so that independent outcomes tend towards the large-number average, when considering, oh I don't know, maybe 60 flips. Provable by experiment. Same with dice, same with any game of chance. That is what that 2nd class in statistics is all about, determining how many times an experiment must be repeated to have a good certainty of the large-number PDF of the experiment.

"Regression to the mean" doesn't mean that if you have exceptionally good performance on one test, then the next time that you take a similar test your performance will not be as good. It means that your performance will TREND to the mean. it doesn't have to trend strictly to the mean. Were that the case, your performance would never vary away from the mean and as such the probability density function for your performance would not be Gaussian...in fact your initial performance would be so unlikely as to be almost impossible for you to ever achieve. This is similar to the fallacy that performance will always improve with repetition, which is worthy of a video of its own.

It's dangerous to use statistics to examine statistical phenomenon closely when you don't really understand the statistics that you're attempting to use. Unless you don't really care about being wrong. The truly funny thing about statistics is that it proves that you will be wrong the more that you try to use it (or to do anything), but as far as I know it doesn't say anything about whether you'll recognize your errors without an improved understanding of statistics. It's quite likely that you'll just get more confused with every repetition.

This is all to do with natural limits and the affect of perception on outcome, which amounts to a self-self-fullfilling cycle. Belief is grounded in expectation, and expectation on that of limits (perceived as real or otherwise). Once you receive that A+ on the test and all the positive outcomes associated with it, the producer of the outcome (the limit) paradoxically establishes the basis for an opposite outcome. Now, regarding research on the subject, if that great game of golf, which was followed by a bad one, was just one game in a multi-game tournament, you would rightly expect another great performance to be met with even greater results, thereby maintaining motivation. But once the natural limit is reached (and it always is), the opposite results and behavior will inevitably ensue (every high is proceeded by a low equal in magnitude). Though often maligned, universal limits exist, and do so for good reason. Such is the basis of perception. Exceeding these limits requires the development of tool which are unnatural and antithetical to their reason for being (such as the grading system or medications which cause worst side affects than what were meant solve). Furthermore, while being maybe a bridge to far, I believe this all to be related to the wave-function in quantum mechanics. A particle with the possibly to produce any number of outcomes, once measured becomes somehow manifest in our shared perception and thus behave as expected. That's because it is impossible for the mind to simultaneously perceive something being two things at once (try to think about not thinking). Outside of this, exists the profundity of paradox (see Schrodinger's cat and double-slit experiment) and the minds inability to grasp the literal nature of things, such as an electron, for example. So while limits can, and often are, temporarily exceed by our perception, the universe will eventually and inevitably regress to mean. As said, "what goes up, must come down"... Ultimately, reality is weird and mysterious, yet so utterly amazing.. thanks for reading.

This is a big reason why government shouldn’t try to legislate our lives. Many times they use statistics to justify a certain policy, without taking into account this regression to the mean phenomenon. For example, if after a mass shooting, strict gun control is instituted and the following year gun crimes go down. Of course, the policy makers will attribute this decline to the new laws, when it is only a random regression to the mean. The next year, they may rise again. In Montana, we had a similar thing happen when for a short time they had “no speed limit” on the highways. One only had to drive at a “reasonable speed for the conditions and for your car”. When the next year, highway deaths rose, there was an outcry for speed limits to be reinstated, and they were. Of course, then the highway deaths declined, and it was attributed to the new speed limits. Problem was, the year following, they rose again, even though the same speed limits were in place. Of course, there was no outcry to eliminate the speed limits again, because laws tend to become stricter, rather than more free.

Arh, I guess your "regression to the mean" is just the opposite of the gambler fallacy. In the later, one wrongly assumes that because the universe will right itself the likelihood of a new outcome will change. In the former, one wrongly assumes that the result will stay the same as before. For both, the truth is that the distribution of the outcomes stays the same if you pick from the same distribution, but depending on the bias of the sampling you might observe a different sampling mean from sampling ing to sampling due to randomness (or "luck").

The difference between the coin and the pilots is that the coin tosses are (theoretically) independent, that is, past tosses don't affect the outcome of future tosses, whereas the pilots' performances obviously depend on the pilot, so future performances by a pilot are expected to be dependent of past performances by the same pilot. That's the difference between the gambler's fallacy and regression to the mean.

LOL... randomness on the macro level is a correct assumption. Eventually all things slide into entropy and "even out". But on a micro level, human beings counteract entropy all the time. A classroom full of students may regress to "the" mean, but an individual will regress to his or her own personal mean, and then only so long as he or she does not apply cognition and effort to improve.

How about a look at those gamblers. The simple fact is that no matter how well you play games in Vegas, if you play long enough the house always wins. BUT... if you play badly enough, you can most definitely lose worse and more consistently than the "average" player. And if you study the game and play as efficiently as possibly, you can most definitely lose more slowly than that same "average" player. In blackjack, the house edge is only .5%, which is the amount that is "baked in" to the game. Even a very good player will eventually lose at that rate. BUT, most players are not that skillful. Those players lose at a rate that is considerably higher than the house edge. They do not regress to the mean - they regress to their own level of skill (or lack thereof, if you prefer). Some at or approaching the house edge, and some considerably worse.

I'm sorry, but you're just misleading people on this one. Each player may regress to his or her personal mean, based on skill. But the mean of the means will be a composite of those different skill levels, and not at all meaningful for predicting the outcome of any individual player or even group of players. And skill levels may well change over time, as players study and improve, which means that maintaining the "mean" depends totally on a new and constant supply of new, unskilled players.

Side topic: The gamblers fallacy confuses the sample size - if you were to flip a coin 100 times trying to get heads just once, the odds do add up that in this overall sequence of 100 flips you will get heads. But if the sequence is just one coin flip the odds of previous flips in previous sequences don't add up - gamblers confuse their continuous experience of prior flips as being the terms for the current sequence of flips. But if the sequence is 100 flips, dude, that adds up (still not a sure thing, but really high chance of getting a single heads in there). Odds (inside a sequence) do add up.

Positive feedback always worked better than negative feedback. Nevertheless, negative feedback is used more, because the response in the people getting the feedback is not the only factor when choosing what king of feedback to give. This is why negative feedback is used more:

1) Positive feedback is often more expensive than negative feedback (prize vs reprimand)
2) The feedback is generally given by a person higher in a hierarchy, negative feedback is used to assert domination
3) Lots of feedback givers enjoy giving negative feedbacks over positive ones
4) Lots of feedback givers think that negative feedbacks work better (it doesn't, but they believe that). It can be thought by cause of personal experiences (like the example in the video, misinterpreting the results) or it can be cultural
5) In most scenarios, good performance (or simple compliance) is expected, so it is not rewarded, and bad performance (or simple deviation) is punished (for example, crime)
6) Positive feedback to specific members of a group can cause envy between members, negative feedback is less likely to cause envy.

This inspired me to do research into the studies that looked at positive vs. negative reinforcement. After carefully reading all the data I have to admit I'm not very convinced by the data. For starters every study seems to use a different definition of what negative and positive reinforcement are so there is no consistency across these studys. Most the studies were short term in nature it's nearly impossible to determine if positive or negative reinforcment is better long term. What about both? A lot of these studies involved extremes. Give one group 100% positive reinforcment and one 100% negative. This is fine but it doesn't establish if either of these methods is superior to an 80 20 mix or a 50 50 mix etc etc. It seems to me the results of this data is very limited. Being 100% positive vs 100% negative over the short term with an extremely disagreed upon definition of what positive and negative are leads to better results for the 100% positive group. Okay but what about how the real world operates? Is there an optimal amount of praise vs. correction over long periods of time that offer optimal results vs. These extreme data sets. I suspect there is and I suspect this also requires a tighter and more universally agreed upon definition of positive and negative reinforcment so we can have an apples to apples comparison.

The United States Army has already developed a solution to this. It's called the "After Action Review" and I find that it's a wholly superior method.

It consists of the following phases.

1. Review of what our goals were.
2. Review of what actually happened. Did we accomplish those goals?
3. What did we do well that helped us accomplish those goals?
4. What did we mess up, and how can we improve more for next time?
5. Develop a more refined game plan for next time.

This takes the 'punishment' element and puts it in a more constructive light. One takes an honest look at what actions could have resulted in failure, but ONLY with the understanding that we're in a learning process.

Punishments/chastisement rarely ever logically work anyway, because:

1. All chastisement runs the risk of demotivating anyone.
2. Those who are truly motivated to do better will continue to do so in spite of the chastisement.
3. Those who are NOT truly motivated to do better will not improve anyway... and require a better incentive (i.e a reward) in order to improve.

This is why the Army focuses on positive feedback, and straightforward constructive criticism.

Now, before anyone starts telling me "Then why do Drill Instructors always yell at new enlistees?"

That is because they are being trained for stress resilience. It is mental hardening. That's a different exercise entirely.

Pissed off at how you have simplified statistics theory to just "regression to the mean". Any statistician would've told you that any study that relies soleily on a one time event to proof causality with a regression, is plainly wrong...

There are a multitude of methods to proof causality, if you are using regression testing, then control groups need to be built, and trial/testing experiments should be run on a k-fold basis. Aside from this on any clinical or real study survival techniques, which give follow up treatment to the same patients, control for the effect of chance and enviromental factors by following the progress of a sickness as more treatment is provided along a period of time, while also controlling with a placebo group.

Finally, most modern studies don't rely on regression anymore... they rely on no normalized techniques like XGBoost, or RandomForest, or even Neural Networks to find effects, but all of them have the same paradigm, a proven effect, doesn't imply causality.

Your whole video relies on that falasy, whereas statisticians have continously told the industry that a simply correlation, or relationship through regression, DOESN'T imply causality.

This is actually researched in the military.
Negative feedback and punishments are a good way to basically dumb people down into simple obedience, this makes them passive, hardened and better at following orders immediately. It's useful for simple tasks and training, oddly enough, flying planes would qualify for that. Physical conditioning, physical tasks with low complexity, hands on challenges all can be motivated well using negative feedback and pointing out flaws will help them identify their error and try to focus and improve that task until they are competent.

Positive feedback is the next phase, using the success they gained from the above, you then build on their confidence by listing their success and gains as they improve. This gets people to believe in themselves and even inspired or capable of improving and being a better person. This is also critical because you need people to be self motivated to learn and master high functioning tasks and complex assignments.

Both are good tools to building people up, too much negative feedback will crush a person and cause problems, too much positive feedback and they feel like they can achieve whatever with no effort.

In the "scientific" studies where participants are randomly assigned to "praise" or "blame" groups, the "praise" group is "statistically" doing better than the "blame" group. Since it's statistical nature, there are people in the "praise" group that are doing worse than some "blame" group people. Which means "praise" works negatively to those minorities and "blame" works positively. Should we suggest a uniformly "golden" rule to "praise" whenever possible? It's a safe bet since regardless whether it helps people, "praise" can always bring good emotion. But should we ignore minorities since it works most of the time?

Thanks very much for your fascinating videos, but regarding regression to the mean and its (mis)/application to human behavior, perhaps it would be helpful to consider the following. Good points about different kinds of tasks and potentially confounding variables (which are almost impossible to control for especially ethically regarding people). There are also different natural ways of learning which have nothing to do with reward and punishment, such as modeling and classical conditioning, the latter of which has apparently been used commercially to pair material goods and services with intangible factors such as freedom and happiness. Regarding tasks, more complex or creative tasks do not necessarily respond best to instrumental conditioning. Furthermore, schedules of reinforcement were found to be a significant factor even in simple straightforward tasks that tend to be suited to instrumental conditioning. Variable schedules of reinforcement were found to be most effective. In other words, chance itself is also in part rewarding to some extent regarding the timing of positive feedback. So best to be positive but not too predictable. :) And for more complex learning, modeling works well but may be sensitive to the primacy effect or initial conditions. So to teach, practice what you preach and best to support genuinely good parenthood and role models. :)

In other words, it is what it is, so hope for the best but prepare for the worst.

I generally agree, but for fighter pilots it is most definitely task oriented. I may be biased, as I flew fighters in the U.S. Navy. It is an unforgiving task which has a likelihood of death (bad) and/or the loss of a $25 million airplane + the death and damage associated with it in carrier operations (worse!). A short YouTube search will bring up plenty of videos of 20 tons of flaming debris sliding across the flight deck from losses of concentration. It has to be driven into students that doing well once does not offset doing poorly another time. In undergraduate pilot training, you are graded on 20+ performance criteria per flight, with progression through (in the case of fighters) several different aircraft and quite a few flights. Any 2 unsatisfactory grades will result in being expelled from the program. There are no second chances, for the most part, certainly no third chances, and that reflects the seriousness of the job. Even once you have a great deal of experience, the pressure doesn't let up. Aboard ship, every pilot is graded on every pass and those results are displayed for all to see! If you consistently do poorly, you could be sent home. From the newest pilot in the squadron to the squadron commander, punches aren't pulled.
In this career progression, pats on the back are few and far between for good reason.

I didn't like the explanation for the difference between the gamblers fallacy and regression to the mean.

For me the difference is better explained as follows. Regression to the mean just means that you had an "extreme" result in the current trial, like getting a high score, the next trial is likely not going to be as extreme, you are likely to get an average score which happens to be lower than your current high score, but not the opposite of your current score.

Gamblers fallacy is slightly different. Gamblers expect that if you get a bad result this time, you will get an equally and opposite good result soon. But the reality is that the future events will average out to the mean (not good or bad), which is not the expected averaging out to a "good" result. That's the fallacy.

This very interesting video could be even more interesting if it addressed how the mean moves over time. Since nothing exists in a vacuum, our attempts to measure and influence do, eventually, move the mean one way or another. The way this video was presented, and I'm sure that wasn't the intent, kind of made it sound like the mean eventually overpowers any attempt to derive meaningful information from cause and effect studies. One place where this becomes extremely obvious is in the movement of price for currencies on the foreign exchange market. There, there is a very strong tendency for price to revert to the mean and revisit previous price levels, but the mean is constantly moving, since price is constantly moving. It becomes much more challenging to figure when things are at an extreme, and when they are actually not because the mean has slowly shifted due to the repetition of certain events (price points) being over represented.

In the the Israeli pilot's case, I think you were right in the first place: it is task-dependent.
Aviation is about strictly adhering to rules and not making mistakes. It's often more important to focus on what NOT to do (by drumming in reactions through repetition), rather than doing something very well.
Because: in a fighter jet, if you do one thing badly, your life can be over in seconds. Or you can kill people. Or destroy an extremely expensive military asset. Forgetting to lower your gear or failing to adjust your flaps is life and death.
But if do something really well, the consequence may not be as profound. Landing your jet dead-centre on the strip is nice and all, but it's also OK if you're a meter or two adrift. It doesn't matter each way.
Another example: it's nice if you complete the barrel roll sequence at the air show, but the main task is to avoid hitting the ground.
i.e. the stakes are much higher in a fighter pilot's appraisal, than say, in a geography test.

This video is misleading.....you have to take into account N-0 which is the number of events that need to occur to overcome the short term variance in order to predict regression to the mean.   For example if I get lucky and have a good game of golf today it doesn't mean that tomorrow I am more likely to be unlucky.  Becuase the sample size is only 2 rounds we are nowhere near the N-0 number (the n-0 is where the law of large numbers kicks in and where the regression to the mean principle becomes statistically valid).   If I was to play 1000 rounds of golf and get lucky on average over those 1000 rounds then I could predict that over the next 1000 rounds I am more likely to be unlucky.   However, round by round or event by event there will be no statistical correlation.

If the Israeli pilots who performed  maneuvers poorly were ill that one day with some illness, which subsequently cleared up, and future performances demonstrated improvement, the feedback had less effect than is being attributed. This would be an example of an outlier. If the last place football team gets a pep talk, and destroys the first place team in a game, then loses the remaining games, this is an outlier. If they are perennially the last place team, expectations would be that any win would be followed by more losses, and at season end, they would post a losing record. Over time, it would be observed that their record historically contains more losses than wins. Pep talks and positive reinforcement make no difference.  Regression toward the mean still occurs.

I take a tact with raising my kids that, outside of some especially egregious errors they make or undeniably commendable successes they have, I remain pretty much neutral in our "post-event analysis" and let them decide how negative or positive the lesson will be.
Anytime one of my kids screwed up, I would first make sure they were OK, and then make sure they realized what the mistake was, but then I would simply ask them, "What did you learn from this?" - and then I won't let them off the hook of answering that question until they answer it.
The best teachers I ever had didn't try to drill knowledge into my head - they just forced me to teach myself in ways that are best suited to how I tend to learn. And they stuck with that tact as long as they saw it was working with me.

Answers to the questions:
1. "This statement is a lie." Answer: Not applicable (define "statement," define "lie").
2. "Veritasium is a real element." Answer: Define "real"; if it merely means "Veritasium exists," then that is true, but if it means it exists as an element on the periodic table--false.
3. "The fox says: Hatee-hatee-hatee-ho!" Answer: see above answers on relativity. If the question refers to an actual fox, the answer is false; if it refers to the music video, the answer is true.
4. "The universe is infinite." Answer: the question is not suitable for a true or false answer since the statement cannot be falsified.
5. "Many worlds is the correct interpretation of quantum mechanics." Answer: see above.
6. "There are six continents on planet Earth." Answer: true, using Boolean logic (as someone in the comments pointed out).
7. "The repeating decimal 0.999... = 1." Answer: true; as a repeating decimal, the number of 9s is infinite, meaning that at some point it is indistinguishable from 1--especially in practical use, but even for theoretical equations.
8. "There are an infinite number of twin primes." Answer: not applicable for a true or false question, since it cannot be reasonably falsified by an individual.
9. "Every even integer >=4 is the sum of two primes." Answer: same as above.
10. "Positive [feedback] is better than negative feedback." Answer: not applicable for a true or false answer, since a unified theory of feedback has yet to be formed; there are many factors which can influence performance, and feedback has not appropriately been isolated from those factors.

Let me clarify what I mean by "falsified": if you know how to prove something false, then you can prove it true as well--but if you can't prove something false, there's no way to prove it true as well. For the universe question, the answer is not falsifiable since the only way to know if the universe is finite would be to observe the edge, which is something we will never be able to do. For the prime questions, it's largely the same, except the way to prove something infinite as "true" in mathematics is to find a rule, an equation, that can be proven to be true no matter what numbers are used as variables. The reason I said those answers can't be falsified is because there's no way an individual could, in the time it would take to fill out that test, both deduce and prove a rule which has yet to be found by dedicated professional mathematicians.

Except everything isn't based solely on luck; traffic accidents are more likely to be caused by bad drivers than they are to be pure luck, because human skill augments the random nature of the universe. A "good" driver can accommodate for a particularly "unlucky" set of circumstances and avoid an accident, where a "bad" driver can get in an accident even in the best circumstances. There's also a whole host of psychology that you ignored in the case of the Israeli fighter pilots: Say the goal of the training is to improve the skill of the pilots, and the feedback is ideally based on the execution of that skill. Let it also be said that humans have a tendency towards unfounded pride (arrogance); in this case, it is likely that the reason the instructors provide negative feedback is to prevent their students from becoming prideful and overestimating their abilities, which can also be a cause of the drop in performance following positive feedback. After all, what is "skill", but the ability to replicate a behavior perfectly regardless of circumstance?

How I see/understand this phenomenon:
Between a number ranging from 1 to 100, if you were to pick exactly one number, you have a 1% chance of picking that exact number, for example a 73. Next time you choose, you will also have the same percent(1%) of getting a number, this time 85.
However, things change when we are referring to a group of numbers like 'greater than' or 'less than.'
If we are at 85, there is a 15% chance of you picking a higher number and a 84% chance of getting a lower number. Thus you are more likely to pick a lower number than before despite the exact number you chose had the same percentage as the previous(85).
So it feels as though the results always regress to the middle of 50, despite each individual number being equally likely. If all options are equally likely, than the average will be the middle.

As a teacher of 4-8th graders, I try to make sure praise is built in to everything I say, including the times when criticism is required.

If a student does particularly well on a test, I make sure they know it. If it is possible, I will make that kind of praise public.

If a student did not do well, and if that is typical for that student (perhaps they always struggle), I will critique what is necessary, but I will always find something to give praise for, as well.

If a student does surprisingly poorly, I will critique in a gentle way, but will generally not praise much. Most likely, that student would not respond to praise because they themselves are unhappy with their performance, and praise from me would sound like pandering.

These are all generalities though; each student's needs are so different.

I know this has to be simplified in order to be fit into a short Youtube video, but I feel like it's taken too far. I know you introduce caveats to avoid this, but most of the rest of the video seems to be implying that everything always moves to "the mean" - which just isn't true.

Take the speed camera example - you can't just say that the rate would "go down anyway" because of regression to the mean. It's certainly a possibility, but there are so many other variables involved that I'd argue you can't just say it would have. Accident hotspots are rarely just a blip one year, they generally have accidents year after year after year. If a speed camera is installed and the rate suddenly goes down to a more "normal" level and remains that way year after year, it's pretty clear that the speed camera WAS responsible and it's not just chance.

Not being an expert I'm probably missing exceptions to this "rule", but I'd assume regression to the mean only works with random chance or normal distribution. Again using the car crash example, the probability of crashing on each individual road is different - you therefore cannot assume that each road would, on average, have the same number of crashes.

I disagree about the statements on road and traffic cameras. If you change just one parameter (add cameras) and the average outcome over a sufficiently long time improves, then the thing you changed had an effect. And even if there was no improvement in one intersection, as long as  the average of all locations where cameras were installed improved, it tells you that the cameras had an effect. That’s the whole premise of statistics. The important thing in situations like this is to collect enough data to average out the influence of other factors.

In this video we are mixing moderate pressure scholastic and average strength students results with elite competitive fighter pilots and extreme life and death pressure as well as resilient and ready for battle minds. High pressure and strong emotional control respond well to negative feedback ... low pressure and a weaker mind respond better to positive feedback. This is about understanding circumstance configuration and the individuals comfort configuration. One plant needs more water one less.

Like, feedback maybe doesn't have an instantaneous effect on the level of somebody in a certain domain, but won't it have a positive effect on the long term? Because even if variability causes small apparent (and illusional) causality on the very next situation (near future) through regression to the mean, the indicators that we think (thanks to some beginning of evidence) carry causality will be confirmed, or not, by long term experience. I do agree with most of what you are saying but, the gamblers fallacy is based off the logic that if there is a 50/50 chance for heads or tails, that if you get heads 3 times in a row the chance to get heads the next time is a 12.5% chance. Also with the Iranian pilot example there is the key fact that with more practice you get better at a certain task, that’s just how the human brain works. So yes there is still a chance to do better or worse the second flight but not 50/50 because the pilot improves. Therefore the pilot example has too many variables to account for in order to be used as an accurate example. When I offer my kid a reward to do something they say "what's the reward?". When I threaten them with a punishment they say "what's the punishment". They then judge whether the reward/punishment is worth the expenditure of effort. In the end, the discomfort of the punishment can often outweigh the reward. And, over time rewards and punishments need to grow as my kids learn to adapt. And when too much praise is given, it proves to my child that they don't need to work quite that hard to achieve a passing level of success.


that being said, I have more than one kid, and they are all different.

If you think about it for 5 seconds you'll see why positive feedback works: in any situation, there's really 10000000 things you can do. Now most actions you can take are stupid. The door is closed ... you could walk into it. You could sit down. You could drop dead. You could hit it ... and of course ... you could open it. So when you give someone negative feedback you've shown him one of the 9999900 things that don't work. When you give them positive feedback by correcting them, you've shown them one of the 10 things that work. So you see: knowing what fails doesn't help you much when it comes to figuring out what works. Knowing what works, by contrast, tells you a lot about what will fail. So of course positive feedback works.

Regarding the calculation of probabilities, the term "luck" is inaccurate. A coin flip or a car crash is not luck or chance, if you knew all the starting conditions and the inputs leading up to the event, you could predict the outcome with very good accuracy. In the coin flip, you'd have to know the density of the air, impulse and vector applied to the coin, distance to landing, ect. The problem is that these things are hard to measure. They are not random however. This sort of slang catch all term implies that we live in an inherently inconsistent universe, in which case any sort of science would be impossible. We live in a universe of causality, and that's why science is possible. The term chance is perfectly fine for referring to mathematical probabilities, but is purely for convenience. Chance is not a thing, and it's not a property of matter. It's simply a theoretical term that is tossed out after careful observation of the factors leading to a certain event.

It is a good explanation about statistics, but unfortunately there is a misconception or misunderstanding on the behavior analysis part. What really reinforces or punishes behavior are natural reinforces, stimuli that are produced by the behavior itself. E.g. the maneuver coming out perfectly reinforces the response of piloting the plane in that specific way. Or: making a bumpy landing decreases the probability of the pilot using the same maneuvers again next time.
Comments like criticism or praise are what we call arbitrary consequences. Their power to increase or decrease probability of a specific response being emitted one more time is significantly lower than that of natural reinforcers.
So most likely the pilot teacher saying something nice or bad really had very little to do with performance, anyway.

Deciding whether to give positive or negative feedback wholly depends on the situation.

Regression to the mean is fantastic for random events but is slightly off when referencing human skill.

Skill can improve (or worsen) over time so that two tests in a row will show a regression but if you plot numerous tests over the course of a year, you can see the change.

Positive feedback works better than negative not because it's positive but because it is typically more informative. If you have a 100 options and 1 is right, you do the 1 right and receive positive feedback, you know to repeat it. If you do one of 99 that is wrong and receive negative feedback, you still have 99 other options to choose from.

"You're too low" doesn't tell you how high you need to be, but "good job" tells you to repeat.

Statistics aside, why does positive feedback work? It provides no information on what should be improved in the future, it's merely a pat on the back. And here's where psychology comes in, pats on the back feel good and what feels good motivates us, with improved motivation better results are not surprising.
But what happens if you provide that same positive feedback to someone who is already motivated to the max? Or to someone who is already used to constant level of positive feedback and is expecting it in the first place? Nothing happens.
So in the first place a question should be asked, what is the reason for sub-par performance? Is it a lack of motivation, a lack of understanding, a lack of information, some external factor? It's not as simple as praising or scolding students, unless you know why you are not getting desired results, your actions are unlikely to solve the problem.

"Positive feedback" is not being praised, and "negative feedback" is not being scolded.

A Positive Feedback Loop is: the more sorties you fly, the more your flight instructors review your flying, a.k.a. "the snowball effect".

A Negative Feedback Loop is, the more sorties you fly, the less your instructors review your flying a.k.a "self-correcting" or "self-balancing" systems.

Using the phrase "positive feedback" to refer to praise and "negative feedback" to refer to criticism, leads to very confusing discussions where people might refer to, for example, runaway climate change as a "negative feedback loop".

Because the term "feedback loop" sounds kinda jargony, people tend to hear it atomically, and parse the phrase "positive feedback loop" as [positive] [feedback loop] and not [positive-feedback] [loop].

This video perpetuates this misunderstanding, and that's disappointing since I know Veritasium is here to spread knowledge, not confusion.

Suggestion: maybe do a video on feedback loops...?

Technically wrong usage of "negative feedback", should be "punishment" instead.


"Positive feedback" is moving from a neutral state to a positive state. (If you get an A I'll give you a $20 allowance)
"Negative feedback" is moving from a negative state to a neutral state. Think of it like removing an already-existing negative stimulus (If you get an A I'll stop making you share toys with your brother)
"Punishment" is moving from a neutral state to a negative state. (If you don't get an A I'll ground you)


tldr; the opposite of positive feedback is punishment, not negative feedback.

If you provide too much confidence, they stop trying to be cautious. Like when you make too mant sharp turns into your driveway. You think "oh I got this," and never make a mistake...until you hit the curb and suddenly you're jolted back to reality; you've been narrowly missing the curb the whole time, and this time you were just close enough to hit it.

And yet, we don't want drivers to be timid and anxious while driving, otherwise they never make the right move out of worry and fear. You never want your driver to be timid, but you don't want them so overconfident that they throw caution to the wind and whip that shoulder turn on a red light like some kind of dumbass.

I think, at least with machines and mechanical prowess, this falls under that idea. Telling your pilots they can always do better makes it so confidence never overtakes caution. They can make advanced maneuvers, but they're always reminded that overconfidence can lead to serious or deadly consequences.

I won't go through 3000 comments to check whether this has been said before. I will just mention that you are misusing the terms "positive feedback" and "negative feedback".

These terms do not mean "praise" and "criticism", respectively.

Positive feedback is a result that produces more of the observed effect. For example, the melting of the polar ice caps leads the Earth to retain more heat, which, in turn, leads to more melting.

Negative feedback is a result that tends to arrest the observed effect. For example, a rise in body temperature results in perspiration, which acts to lower body temperature.

Please do not misuse these terms.

Way off in this one! A large part of doing well is in the visualization, an important form of practice for a skill or task. Negative feedback for pilots is incentive to visualize themselves correcting. Negative feedback for students is incentive to study or visualize more. Positive feedback for pilots carries only the weakest incentive, and if anything sends the message that the task is learned, focus on other things. Positive feedback in class sends the message to keep on going as you are (that study and visualization are working), or even that you can focus a bit less, and still get by with a decent lesser grade. In short, positive input tells us to relax and endulge, and negative tells us to adapt or improve, that more work is needed.

There’s a memory issue here as well in the anecdotal cases.
We’re more likely to remember the perceived effect of negative feedback because negative emotions stand out way more in memory than expected, positive emotions.
So while keeping a positive outlook on an unfavorable outcome might be more effective, we’re more likely to forget the times when it does work, at least in contrast to the times when negative feedback appeared to be effective.

Gamblers fallacy fails because gamblers assume that common events will inevitably lead to less common events, but that isn't the case. One should always assume the likely future outcome will be the most likely isolated outcome, and with gambling, that nearly always means you lose. Regardless of how poor or well you have been doing, you will ALWAYS more likely lose. Even if you lose a million times in a row, you will still more likely lose, because you always more likely lose, and nothing about losing a million times in a row is abnormal at all. If anything, it would simply be abnormally typical.

It's good to have both positive and negative feedback. The positive feedback helps you focus on the things you did that lead to success, while the negative feedack helps you focus on avoiding the things that lead to failure.

The presenter uses the expression "negative feedback" incorrectly. What he means is "negative comments" Negative feedback is sending back the output of a system to the input, in opposite polarity, so it tends to stabilize the system. For example: I am steering a car and I see that it is drifting to the right, and I correct steering to the left, and so on and on. That is an example of a negative feedback loop. Any evaluation which results in a correction is an example of negative feedback, whether the evaluation is positive or negative. A negative evaluation of test performance may result in a negative feedback loop in which the student buckles down, or in a  positive feedback loop in which the student becomes more frustrated, develops a mental block or quits the class. A positive evaluation may result in a negative feedback loop in which the student does even better, or a positive feedback loop in which the student decides that he or she is smart enough not to have to study for the next test.
If this is true, then odds are that I'm going to become pretty kickass for the rest of my life.

I believe it's about the importance. If it is important, negative feedback tends to be better, on the converse less important tasks REQUIRE positive feedback. The reason I believe this is because of my son. If he can interdependently find importance in a task then I don't need add anything to keep him paying attention. As a matter of fact I find that it works best to subtract his inappropriate actions. As he finds a natural value of the task, he doesn't like the subtraction or distraction from the task, so he avoids the behavior in the future. However, if does NOT find natural value or importance in the task then he will tend toward not doing it in favor of something more valued or doing it poorly to "get it over with". These are the times I give positive feedback. I have to add something to the task for it to be worth it.

In the fighter pilot example, even though they are two very different people, I will pretend they are carbon copies of one as you do in the video. This assumes that the type of feedback has no preference and does not have any unintended interactions with the ego. Both of the pilots feel their task is important. The one that received positive feedback was focused on the things he did well. He likely did those things again, however the entire run wasn't copied even if that was the goal like in racing. So we can assume the actions that the praised 'good' remain, but there were un-praised 'good' moments that would be missing resulting in a poorer performance. The pilot that received negative feedback had those 'bad' actions removed with no affect on the other actions of the run, so even if he did not make as many 'good' actions he would still have a gain over his last performance.

If your goal is to improve, say, athletic performance, then confidence and enthousiasm would be very important things to gain. If your goal is to stop your team from reckless errors, negative feedback may be the better option ;).

I took psychology in college, and I've read other psychology books, and done other various online research. When we receive positive feedback, the reason we may do worse the next time is being we feel more confident and we don't need to be as careful, or as prepared. If I get a 90% on a difficult test, and I feel very good about that, possibly receiving reward for it, then with my rise in self-confidence I feel less inclined to study harder for the next test, and so I do worse. When we are anxious about something in the future, we focus on it more to prepare for it. But when we feel confident about it, we feel less of a necessity to prepare.
So a sense of self-confidence can (sometimes) hinder our chances of future success.
That's not to say we should never be confident or always feel anxious. But don't let the reward of/from success make you feel like you don't need to try as hard for future successes.

I think this video could have done a little more to clarify the difference between regression to the mean and the gambler's fallacy, because to be perfectly honest, some of the phrasing in this video describes them as very nearly the same thing (nothing explicitly wrong, but some of it was quite vague).

For example, one could reword the gambler's fallacy to something like "my last 5 flips were all tails, so my next flip isn't as likely to be as unlucky", and it sounds virtually the same as how you described regression to the mean.

From where I sit, there are 2 ways of clarifying it. The first is that while they both tend to refer to a streak of good or bad luck and and based on the likelihood that eventually "luck" will average out, the gambler's fallacy assumes to force this "evening out" on the next coin flip. Whereas regression to the mean typically refers to an average over several more flips. Basically, the difference is that regression to the mean describes how we expect the average to behave over time, whereas the gambler's fallacy is a fallacy because it attempts to attribute that behavior to a specific outcome.

The other clarification refers to a concept of an "average result". Such as the random test example where students are more likely to wind up in the middle than at the extremes (tossing a pair of die would be another example). In this case, because the average is more likely than the extremes, that when you get an extreme result once, that the next result is more likely to be closer to the average than it is to be even more extreme. The factor to remember here, is that if you remove the reference to the first result, the statement is simply the original description of the distribution (ie it's more likely to be closer to the average than at the extremes). So in this case regression to the mean is really just a restatement of the probabilities.

Regression to the mean has an impact for sure, but there's something else you hinted at here that matters a lot: biology. Hormonal levels.

Praise usually increases testosterone levels while negative feedback lowers them. Some activities benefit from having high testosterone blood levels, while others (which probably include flying a fighter jet) benefit from having it lowered.

There's also a psychological fault with praise. When you tell someone that they did amazingly, something that subconsciously transpires is "the height of your performance right now is beyond what is sufficient to accomplish the task, so in the future, do not feel pressed to reach these heights". As one of my former high school teachers used to say, "A genius can choose to achieve adequacy with little effort or greatness with a lot of effort. Both are perfectly valid choices."

All in all, I feel like negative feedback does not work for the average person, but the optimal mindset to have in order to reach and overcome ceilings is to be the type of person who gains more out of negative feedback than positive.

Or, potentially, a pilot got too confident after receiving positive feedback, and another pilot was more careful after receiving negative feedback.

With regards to the fighter jet example, here's my take on it.

The pilots who did poorly don't want to repeat their failures, so they put greater efforts (are under more stress) in order to perform well. On the other hand, the good pilots get a little bit comfortable with their excellence and don't put as much effort into subsequent trials. So, they perform less than before. So it could also have a lot to do with the level of stress they're under.

Actually. That kind of feedback is very useful in the world of employment. If a person is given a 5.0 (5 out of a possible 5) as a surprise midyear evaluation, and then their end of the year Evaluation that determines raises shows they are down from that 5 to a 4.5 or less, this gives many Managers the argument of no raise that year. This was used by Kinko's (before it became FedEx Office). At mid year the managers would give the Mid-Year evaluation as a way to help the employees know where they are lacking to help them improve. However, that mid-year evaluation was counted against them at the end of the years evaluation. More over, the Managers were told to give at least one if not two points higher for the Mid-year evaluation. So, there you go. This kind of feedback has it's advantage in the business world to save money and reduce giving raises. Additionally, many employees that stayed with the company actually worked harder, put in more hours, and strove to do a better job the next year. In most cases, it was not until the start of the 4th or 5th year that the employees came to realize they are never getting a raise or the raise will be only pennies on the hour ( 2 to 3 cents per hour). This also helps people understand why the employees that were horrible at a Kinko's were typically the long term ones who no longer cared about how they did, and the good employees often left by the start of the 3rd year (if that long), having gone yet another year with out a raise.

For example, lets say you walk under a ladder. Your mother scalds you, saying that it is dangerous to walk under a ladder. This is negative feedback, because you are applying a stimulus in response.
Now lets say that you walk under a ladder, and then a few hours later you loose your wallet. You were going to loose your wallet either way, but your brain tries to find the pattern in the event. You may have heard that walking under a ladder causes bad luck, or perhaps you also lost your wallet last time you walked under a ladder, so you associate the ladder to the loss of the wallet.

First, regression TOWARD the mean (not "TO the mean) is a more accurate statement (he keeps saying "to the mean"). This phenomenon is associated with random events or variables. And, as he says, there is an element of chance or randomness in human performance. However, for example, Usain Bolt, after earth shattering performances, has not regressed to the mean. His performances have regressed slightly TOWARD the mean. Usain Bolt is still out of this world in his times. In general, take any high performing human being, like an athlete that scores a record number of points in a season. Of course, the next year that same athlete is likely to regress TOWARD the mean. But they will not regress TO the mean. They will not become an average performer.

Excellent video. One thing though the technical terms would be punishment, and positive,negative reinforcement. Negative reinforcement is removing a stimulus, etc. Its been a few years perhaps terminology.

I have noticed some people confusing punishment with negative reinforcement. The idea of punishment is not to reinforce a behavior, but to discourage a behavior.
So, to clarify what negative reinforcement is, when the word "negative" is used, instead thing "subtractive". You are removing, or subtracting an unpleasant stimulus in consequence of a given behavior.
Example: when you put your seat belt on, the annoying beeping stops. This reinforces the behavior of wearing a seat belt.
Another example: when a cigarette addict begins feeling the withdrawal effects, smoking a cigarette very quickly removes the withdrawal effects, and reinforces smoking behavior.

I think all the theories you spoke of were valid. Regression to the mean is definitely valid, considering that all occurrences are influenced by chance in one way or another.

On the subject of positive reinforcement or negative reinforcement, well it definitely does depend on the task or the situation. Some problems ARE NOT the result of the absence of knowledge or capability. Some problems could very easily be related to something as simple as confidence. So positive reinforcement would actually boost confidence, if that was what was lacking.

However if it is something related to technical capacity, then perhaps negative reinforcement could be more useful. Take football (soccer), for example, which I follow religiously. There are strikers with World class ability that fall into lulls, periods where they just cannot seem to score. What happens is simply that their psychology begins to influence their results moreso than anything else, including regression to the mean. And the more they don't score, the lower their confidence sinks. Strikers have been known to get a lucky goal out of nowhere and that lucky goal, is what brings them out of the lull.

The reverse is also true. Strikers that are "In form", are not simply strikers with a high ability, they are strikers with high confidence.

So it really does depend on the task. Aside from confidence, we can also consider other factors such as passion...but I will stop here.

with the rugby players i have to point out correlation and causation. 

Let's just assume you have 10 players on a team and 5 of them are good players, 5 of them are bad players.

You separate these 10 players into two groups of G,B,G,G,B and B,G,B,B,G. Good and bad players

You show group A highlight reels and positively reinforce. Naturally the good players are going to receive this positive reinforcement because they played well.

You show group B highlight reels and negative reinforcement. Naturally the bad players are going to receive this negative reinforcement because they played bad.

Next game comes around and your 3 good players from group a are playing just as well because why not? Just as the 2 bad players from group a are playing just as bad because they are just bad players. 3 bad players from group b are playing just as bad and the 2 good players from group b as playing just as well. 

You find that the 3 good players from group A that were positively reinforced had higher testosterone.

You could conclude that good players are good players because they naturally have more testosterone and feedback doesn't actually make a difference.

There is indeed a factor of luck that plays into the success or failure of the student. However, it cannot be assumed that regression to the mean is the sole factor that influences the result.

Significance of Means:
Veritasium is assuming that the mean is equivalent across positive and negative feedback. That is to say, a Palm tree's growth rate is the same no matter what climate you place it in. There will be variability about the mean survival rate, but the mean survival rate of palm trees will differ drastically across climates. As such, there exists noise in almost every system, but that is not to say we shouldn't search for more optimal climates.

Jet Flying and Obscure Tests:
The parallel between the performance on flying a jet and performance on obscure tests is poor grounds for the argument. Regression to the mean is statistically significant in obscure testing because probability is solely influenced by randomness. Flying a jet is not a chaotic system, (otherwise we would have 50% chance of dying every time we flew). I believe this argument is invalid, as the foundation, which assumes equivalent relevance of regression to the mean in both systems, fails to apply to the facts presented.

I have an issue with this video. He says that we use a control to see if the results of the drug aren't just chance. But that's not true. If we wanted to test for chance, we wouldn't need a control. We would only need to see if the test group was statistically significant from the average BEFORE the drug trials. If they weren't, then we shouldn't even sample from them at all. We never should. A simple random sample would never choose the last 10% of people. The point of a control is to see if the positive effects are due to a placebo or not. This is different from what he says.

Also, with the traffic light scenario, there is a way to see if the accidents are due to chance or not BEFORE installing a camera. If, when we test the proportion of traffic accidents at that intersection against the average in that city or town using a 1-proportion z test, and the p-value is small enough, we can then install traffic cameras. If it's too big (usually above 0.05), then we don't install the cameras. 

It's very important to be precise with statistical language. It's quite easy to mess it up. I love Veritasium, but Derek should be more careful.

This video is a pretty good start, just understand that its incomplete because of its linearity. The Universe is quantum and multidimensional, not linear. To simplify that for you I will just say: reality is a cake, not a light switch.

This video uses light switch physics. A series of probabilities for a single set of on and off function. Life is not quite so simple. The Universe is a fractal and you have tons of multiple simultaneous things happening at once, and on all scales of reality.

For example -- everything is made of everything else, up and down the scale from the micro to the macro. You see the same basic fundamental patterns repeating as you rise up from the atomic, to the cellular, to planets and stars, to galaxies, galaxy clusters, super clusters and so on. The exact same interactions are at play regardless of who or what is doing what, or on what level of the scale.

Change one ingredient of a cake just slightly, or add or subtract an ingredient, and you have a VERY DIFFERENT CAKE. In fact, a very slight change will turn cake into bread, and vice versa.

Explaination to neg-pos feedback in army.

As an ex-squad leader/solder myself, israeli flighters or any soldiers are purposely given negative feedbacks. It is not just about tasking quality. The instructor needs to keep his status above trainee to subordinate the soldiers. Trust me on this, negative feedback boosts awareness but decreases self-esteem(testosterone!) and motivation. On the other hand, positive feedback boosts self-esteem and motivation.

It is good to have positiveness in a squad but too much fails the maintain squad form. Army runs in group not individuals! You cant have privates being super motivated thinking he can make a difference in tasks. Just no. Absolute no!

Officers want their soldiers to be 99% aware at all times. Awareness has lead many "prevents" of losses in battles. Lower self esteem is easier to control than higher. This is why mammalian animals that hunt in packs are structured this way--say wolves or dogs.

So there is one problem with negative feedback and that is motivation. Therefore, army motivates soldiers thru~ rewards: ranks, badges, medallion, or even return home vacation.

Corporates work differently so dont get mixed. But you can assume any task force related companies require this kind of structure.

Hi Derek,

I have a degree in Consumer Behaviour; very well explained. One thing that you may want to look at is personality type, I won't go into too much detail as it is quite easy to find - some of Eysenck' research on the Big V.

One's level of extroversion plays a role in what type of feedback works better for them, more introverted subjects respond better to negative feedback and more extroverted subjects respond better to positive reinforcement, this basically goes back to loss aversion and the idea that introverts are much more loss aversive than extroverts; for example positive reinforcement would make an extrovert feel rewarded, by nature they are more likely to seek out gains, and the positive reinforcement would stimulate this, the opposite applies for extroverts. Of course when you take a random sample of the population this effect would be averaged out, but it is still interesting and certain disciplines that attract particular personality types - academics are generally quite high in introversion, sales people are generally high in extroversion - could be treated differently based on this.

Keep the videos coming, I think you and other channels like Vsauce, Smarter Every Day, Numberphile, Steve Mould, etc. are doing a great thing, stimulating scientific thinking in youth and getting people to question things that they may read or see in the news. 

Thinking Fast and Slow is also a fantastic read that I would recommend.

one important thing that is missing from the scope of the Israeli Airforce example (and from some of the major studies) - the relationship between the punished/rewarded and the punisher/rewarder. There are different kinds of "educators" in people's lives, that differ according to your relationship to them. A teacher who is outgoing and positive will better motivate you by giving you a gold star and promises of future stars for good work. Another teacher who is more strict and serious that manages to become a "father-figure" with an "aura of a genius" would get more out of you if he seems "disappointed" in your results.
The same thing goes with military commanders. While you may hate them at the beginning of boot camp, after a few weeks you are psychologically programmed to never want to disappoint them. If they "break character" at any point during training - they lose most of their influence. So if they berrate you for making a bad flight - you will try to do better. If they ignore you for making a good flight - you'll try to recreate your achievement in the hope of getting recognition. If they congratulate you for making a good flight - you have nowhere to go...

I don't think the whole regression to the mean idea is accurate.
If you flip a coin once, and it lands on heads, the rule dictates that it has a 75% chance of being tails the next time, but that's only true before you do anything.
You can predict that it will likely not be the same thing twice only before you try it. Once you flip the coin, the likelihood that it will be the same thing twice actually rises to 50%. The past does not influence the future.

Humiliation, scolding and punishment is really more about releasing stress than helping someone or something preform better. Yes you want their behavior to improve, but the aggressive reaction is more due to your own lack of patience and discipline.

Take spanking. A parent that spanks their kids out of anger isn't going to get as good of long term results simply because they probably are going to be inconsistent with the punishment. Furthermore their lack of inconsistency may lead to them losing their temper later on once they had enough of the behavior.  A consistent parent or parents will address the behavior before it becomes an annoyance and the child will move away from the behavior before it becomes a habit. This is one reason why most studies on spanking tend to show that the more a child is spanked the worst their behavior is. The other is the child with the worst behavior tends to get spanked more while the child with better gets spanked less. So punishment may be effective in correcting behavior, but only if its used consistently.

As for rewarding I'll admit that I tend to stop trying as much once someone rewards me. Rewarding may make people feel like they reached their goal causing them to stop trying as much. This doesn't mean people shouldn't be rewarded. It just means that it shouldn't be used prematurely.

The video is incorrect. I do not agree with the proof. 

Yes chance pays a part but so does motivation and a slew of various other factors. The assumption that chance has some equal, implied to be very high, percent in everything is just not proven at any point in the video.

If you have a person who studies and a person who doesn't then you can easily see the person who studies almost always getting better results. This is not to say "study" is the variable missing, what the video is missing/ignoring is literally everything possible, other then extremely dumb luck. In the fighter jet example the pilots who performed badly are likely to get themselves killed if they make a mistake, so you have to account for "motivation" and "incentive" which all the other examples (given the context of the experiment plays a huge part) lacked! nobody dies in an exam, and sports players don't worry about it in game because there are people who worry for them; not the case for dangerous jobs like being (a) in the damn military (b) flying at the speed of sound in a tin can.

The only conclusion of the video is that if we all did everything randomly and our actions were completely and utterly coin flips every time then positive feedback works better, or is just as good as negative.

In real life though, assuming social barriers like "feelings" and "lack of good words" don't get in the way negative feedback (that's not just some blatant attack) provides more "potentially" useful, and at the very least informative, nuggets of information then positive feedback. It's just play useful to know "this is wrong, because of this," as opposed to "good job." The only real benefit to positive feedback is enforcing cultural ties we consume daily like junk food. Any time you get information from it is really just implied negative feedback in a nice package: "you did good, ie. potentially all the other scenarios and possible options were kind of less-good"

3:18 Gambler's Fallacy is actually not as much a fallacy as people think, and I don't know why it's so misunderstood. Maybe the name confuses people. Of course a heads coin flip will increase the probability of a tails flip following, but not with mathematical precision. It is not useful for being a successful gambler, but just for the sake of it, your chance of getting the other result increases with accumulating coin flips of the one result only, because otherwise you couldn't get an average in the long run.
Generally though a very good video for raising awareness about statistical fallacies.

Why is it we find things mutually exclusive when they aren't?  Positive and negative feedback are not mutually exclusive, and in my experience work the best in conjunction with each other.  This possibility was almost completely ignored by the video, only one small section showed varying positive and negative feedback.

We humans seem to like these nice cut and dry groups, positive feedback vs negative feedback, leader vs follower, ect.  The problem is these nice groups we like to create are not representative of the real world.  For example, why can't you be both a leader and follower?  I put forth that a good leader knows when he must follow, therefore a good leader is also a good follower.

Is it possible that someone is neither a leader or follower?  There are people that are terrible leaders, and really can't follow very well either.  Where to they fit in?

Once we have said groups in our minds we also leave out other possibilities.  As an example, what if I excel at doing things on my own?  Where does that fit in the leader/follower groups?  I'm not leading and I'm not following?

All I'm trying to say is be ware of your nice groupings and what you assume about them.

While the statics of this argument are very solid, I'm not so sure that I'm comfortable with the words "reward/punishment" and "feedback" being used interchangeably.  Feedback can really be any sort of thing or things that you receive as a result on any given input, but rewards and punishments imply consequence (meaning "if you do this, I'll give you that," good or bad.)  And there are actually a LOT of studies that show both rewards and punishments having equally negative impacts on participant performance, as well as killing interests and likelihood of repeating the activity, but neutral/informational feedback (over time) has shown consistent improvement in both ability and sense of agency in the participants. As a thought to seriously consider... Reinforcement and feedback are different concepts. Not that I think it changes the conclusion much when probability is being discussed, but that they are physically and psychologically not the same.

Negative reinforcement will for instance likely affect a persons self worth and performance on a long term basis if consistent, whereas negative feedback is simply natures way of keeping a system from running out of control; and is not necessarily something that gets personalized.

This may seem a bit like semantics, but the subtle differences in these ideas is significant.

One thing to keep in mind is the word reinforcement. Too many people think the punishment and negative reinforcement re the same things. Reinforcement is designed to case repetition of a behavior, whether it is positive or negative.

Statistical analysis is always a diversion from analyzing actual relationships between causes and effects because correlation shouldn't imply causation but always has that effect because of the cognitive bias toward connecting the dots when correlates are presented together.

If you want to know what causes fighter pilots, students, or anyone else to perform as they do, you have to analyze the specific situation, identify pertinent causal factors, and trace those factors back through subsequent roots of causes that influenced them.  

It's too simplistic to say that some law of statistical averages causes subsequent events of the same type to regress toward the mean.  It may be ultimately true in an abstract sense but it tells you nothing about the actual causes and influence of each specific situation, whether it's a testing situation, car crash, or fighter maneuver.  

Statistics = lost in the repetitiveness of similarities

I read a rather interesting book recently called "Starfish".

Part of the plot consisted of these computers made with cloned brain cells. Essentially they perform tasks based on positive reinforcement because once they do a job well and are told to repeat the same task in the same manner, more nerves are grown along that path allowing for easier flow of electricity/thought etc.

This causes 3 problems. 1) In certain situations where an action that is normally positively reinforced is the wrong choice they will still make it. 2) In complex tasks they will defer to simple logic to solve it (eg. get one to take 1,000 tests each offering a or b answers then give it a test with options a,b c, d and e... It will choose options a or b when the answer isn't immediately apparent because a and b have been positively reinforced more often). 3) The same way they grow more nerves to perform reinforced choices. They will deteriorate information that is not considered useful. Essentially they're all amnesiacs.
