clearly he didn't understand the nature of pilot training at all. Or the nature of pilot trainees, who tend to be highly competitive.
Pilot training has to reinforce the very real negative consequences of making mistakes, as those mistakes get people killed.
At the same time it also reinforces the very real positive consequences of excelling at things, as that increases the success rate of the entire group.

It has been found, and any good trainer knows that, that using either negative or positive reinforcement exclusively doesn't work well. You need a balanced mix of both.
Thus a trainee fighter pilot gets verbal lashings, maybe even grueling physical exercise, as a result of making (repeated) avoidable mistakes.
But that same trainee, if he excels and does better than is expected of him at the stage of training he's in, gets rewarded.
This not only reinforces the idea that excellence is to be tried for individually, but it also creates a spirit of competition in the group to be the best of the group, as those too get special benefits.
And the best group of the program as a whole gets special benefits as well.
Meanwhile, the worst performers get given dirty jobs like cleaning out toilets, which makes them all the more eager to do better in the future so they won't have to do that again.
Of course a good trainer also knows to not overdo either side, that toilet cleaning crew will need to have the time to study and practice or they'll never improve (and that's where in the past things went wrong, and sometimes still do, as some trainers are sadists who just pile on the abuse for abuse's sake, driving their victims into the ground to the point they give up).

Something was bugging me about the logic of this video and it just hit me what it is. (Bear with me - this is a monster of a "comment.")

Assuming that you're right with your standardized test example, it makes sense that if - for instance - you get 100/100 on a test, and then you retake it, chances are (speaking in terms of probability) you're going to get less than 100/100 the next time.

This works for quantifiable ceilings (and floors - such as 0/100) because the inherent belief is that you can do no better than 100/100 and no worse than 0/100. But if we delve into more subjective examples, where the ceilings and floors are highly arbitrary and ill-defined (such as acting) the logic of it becomes increasingly psychological.

Matthew McConaughey, for example, won an Oscar this year. Imagine if he were to say "that was the peak of my performing ability" (the acting equivalent of a perfect score - 100/100). Using the logic from before, that would mean that he's likely to do a somewhat worse job in his next big performance.

However, the real McConaughey said that his hero is himself in 10 years. What this means is that there's an older, all-around-better version of himself that he believes he can always reach. In other words, he doesn't believe that there is a ceiling for his abilities. So the "ceiling" logic of his next performance being worst than his last may not actually apply because he doesn't believe it was his best possible performance.

I think this psychological distinction is important to note because standardized testing internalizes this idea that you have a floor and ceiling to your abilities, and you can't stretch above or below those areas, which is incredibly limiting to believe! And if you apply the logic of your video here to a ceiling that you believe you have, then it makes sense why some people fail before they even get started: They don't believe that they can grow beyond a certain point.

It also adds some weight to the motivational tough-coach routine, like the techniques used in the movie "Miracle." The coach provided some harsh feedback and some kind feedback, but that ultimately wasn't the point. The point was that he wanted them to believe that they could get better. And better. And better. And he insisted that he knew they had more ability in them than what they were offering.

In short, he broke their limiting, psychological ceiling.

I've always had a problem with the gamblers fallacy. It's main presupposition is that chance is real, which in general I reject, at least at the superatomic level. Sticking to the coin flip example, each flip is not really a 50/50 chance. Indeed, the result of each flip is predetermined once the coin leaves the flipper's hand, and is dependent upon factors such as the strength and angle of the flip, weather conditions, etc. There are machines that have been built showing this concept. The concept of a 50/50 comes from the observation of a pattern which exists within coin flipping, but has nothing to do with individual flips; somewhat similar to how individuals define statistics, but statistics do not define individuals. Given this, while past flips do not affect future flips, you can look to the past to predict the future.
I'll give you an example.
Suppose you flip a coin a large number of times, a hundred, maybe a thousand times, and the results of said flips are recorded, "H" for heads, "T" for tails. If you were to look to this ledger of flips would you suppose to find more instances of 3 of the same in-a-row, or more instances of 4 in-a-row? Logic would lead us to say more instances of 3 given the larger probability of doing such. From this we can conclude that when given the 3 in-a-row situation, more times than not the next flip is going to be an instance of the opposite side of the coin. This seems to refute the gamblers fallacy, at least within this specific instance.

There are so many variables when doing psychological experiments that there is no such thing as a "control."  This is why feedback should remain neutral.  No "good job" or "you should have done this better."  Simply, "I saw this in your work," or just show the complete footage of the work.  If you think saying "good job" is going to raise test scores, you are wrong.  You will create an over inflated sense of ego if you continually praise, causing the subject to stop trying so hard or stop caring about the work that is being done, unless it is to receive a reward.  Conversely, if you berate the subject or the work, you will deflate the ego to the point the subject doesn't care or want to even attempt the work.

A lot of people in the comments still don't seem to grasp the difference between gamblers fallacy and regression to the mean.

Gamblers fallacy: "10 coinflips in a row comes up heads? Then the next 10 is sure to have all tails!"

Regression to the mean: "10 cointflips in a row comes up heads? Then the next 10 is probably going to have 50% to come up tail!"
The "gamblers fallacy" capitalizes on the principle that the coin toss results will regress to the mean, so how is it a fallacy?

This isn't accurate for all scenarios. Some scenarios have such small factors of luck that the "returning to the mean" theory is irrelevant. 

Example: Running. If I run 1 mile and my coach says it was bad and I'm holding up the team, itll affect my next run. Similarly, if he says it was ok but he has confidence that I can do much better, it'll also affect my run. Now how much it affects me depends on my personality and how I, specifically, respond to different types of feedback. Running is 90% mental, 10% physical, and 0% luck.

Now there are some instinctual reactions to feedback that don't vary too much. They are reliable and effective with the only problem being that it is negative feedback. Proof that negative feedback works better than positive lies in San Diego and Parris Island, at Marine Corps Recruit Training. Recruits are yelled at, scolded, insulted, embarrassed, harassed, all in the name of physical training and learning. And it works. No other "program" can make the changes in a person, physically and mentally, as effectively and efficiently as the Marine Corps.

Just my perspective.

And here is the real problem: you have to give people something they can achieve and then praise them for achieving it.  If you give someone a capable goal and then they achieve it, praising them is great.  If you give someone a capable goal and they do NOT achieve it then praising them for trying or chastising them for failing, in my mind, would have similar outcomes (perhaps praising them for trying might be slightly better).  But if you give someone a goal that they are NOT capable of achieving then it doesn't matter either way. 

You should not be positive for no reason--people (and especially children) see right through fake praise.  If you praise them for nothing, then you devalue praise.  Soon even when children accomplish something, your praise is not heard because they were always getting praised anyway--they aren't going to think they actually accomplished anything.

How do you know that the fighter pilot tests were biased?  How do you know the experiments affirming positive reinforcement weren't biased?  Assuming a neutral teacher, one just as likely to give positive reinforcement as negative reinforcement, then if the class is better (randomly) then he will likely give more positive feedback vs. negative feedback and likewise if the class is worse, the teacher will likely give more negative feedback than positive feedback.  If it's the quality of the class that determines the amount of positive vs. negative feedback then how can you possibly argue that the amount of positive/negative feedback predicts the class (when in fact it would be the other way around).

I am very skeptical of research on teaching because often times they select the best classes to experiment on.  It's real easy, I have a great idea.  Who should we test it on?  Lets test on the AP students!  After the study the AP students do slightly better.  Great this teaching technique works!  Or was it one of the 1,000 other variables that you could never possibly control for when it comes to teaching and learning?

Negative feedback encourages strength and fortitude. Positive feedback encourages compassion and acceptance.
Both are necessary in education. The externalities are totally irrelevant in aggregate preferably in a controlled study for which I'm sure there is ample referential evidence. 

But where do you draw the line?

It depends on both the pupil and the challenge at hand, directed or not.
It is up to the mentor to be the fountain of wisdom, not the pupil. That has quite a few variables of personality associated with it, but over time and many observations it is largely consistent through many studies. Interdependence is not an alien result.

Self education is very tricky, however, in this respect because they must rely on their material to be the mentor in both respects. They must be able to scold themselves and reward. 

It can happen but it is a very wary and uncertain road since there is hardly measurable a developing of a bonding and trust throughout the process other than in the knowledge itself and the reaction from the outside world.

An example - congratulating a drug addict for not doing drugs is seen as a positive experience, however, the act of not doing the drugs in the first place is the norm (there is no praise). So, in order to be praised for drug use you must first create a problem in order to be congratulated on your abstinence.

Of course the idea that the action was or wasnt wrong in the first place is also necessary. If you give feedback someone who already believes they are doing something correctly (or doesn't have a desire to improve) they will be less apt to receive the advice (more likely to take it negatively) - someone telling you how to do your job, as example.

On the flip side, when given negative feedback a person would be less likely to desire to improve unless a practical solution is provided as morale may be lowered. This would directly correspond to the detriment of the task. Fighter pilots are likely to be under extreme circumstances and the result of failure could be a life/death situation - so praise for skill would result in a careless mind-state which would not had been appropriate for the situation.

Its context sensitive -

The general solution is to identify the problem from the perspective of the individual. Give negative feedback on the negative things (so you and the individual know what the problem is - and know that you both know it) and neutral feedback on the positive things (to stabilize morale and reinforce the necessity of those actions).

In operant conditioning, the closer in time the consequence (positive or negative) occurs to the behavior, the more effective the reinforcement. Fixed ratio, coins in soda out, extinguishes quickly when soda doesn't deliver. Intermittent ratio, cherries on slot machine, coins run out before behavior extinguishes. "When your dad gets home you'll get a licking" is negative reinforcement to being with dad, but does not consequence the "bad behavior." That is why most punishment does not work, and the conditions that supported the behavior in the first place (poverty, lack of supervision) are not addressed. Skillfully applied positive reinforcements cannot be resisted, conversely punishment can be resisted to the death.

I'm skeptical of the hypothesis you posed about the Israeli pilots. Standards in fighter pilots are very high, and while it's expected for pilots to improve, it's not expected for pilots to get worse (although randomness and other factors allow for this). Even if the regression to the mean can distort the numbers, if you quantify a pilots performance, and expect the average pilot to score a 90 out of 100, then a pilot who is averaging a 50 will expect his score to change significantly with more experience, whereas a pilot who averages a 95 still has a margin to work with. I'm fairly certain that the Israeli Air Force is aware of how statistics work, and how psychology works for that matter.

Though regression to the mean is valid there are other determining factors not addressed. Such as:
0:55 VISUAL PROGRAMMING:
The distinction here was the video process. See, by show the players a video, positive or negative, it doesn't matter because visually reinforcing something in the mind of a viewer will cause that pattern or result to be repeated. This can also be accomplish through repeated detailed mental visualization of perfect performance. Olympic athletes regularly use this in their training.
PEER PRESSURE
The training of military aviators includes the expectation that they must be flawless & idolization of their superiors whom they seek to please. So when these superiors reprimand them (usually in front of the team), they suffer a level of embarrassment & seek to improve so as not to disappoint these superiors they admire. This works on the basis of peer pressure & the desire to fit in. This technique doesn't work so well with internally motivate people, mainly externally motivated cadets.

I can personally relate to this statistical phenomenon. 
 After not having done so for months or even years, I've gone out to shoot a couple rounds of Trap (its shotgun shooting sport) or had gone rolled a couple games of bowling.
In every case, my first round of Trap, I would shoot 23-24 trap out of the 25 targets and likewise my first game of bowling, I'd score of 195 or above, however, any following attempts at either sport, always yielded a less impressive score....15 for Trap and 123 for bowling.
After years of seeing this phenomenon, (I'm 60 yrs old)  I discovered that there were two common denominators in each sport. 
Firstly, I had developed the biomechanical skills from years of practice. Secondly,
I had experienced a sense of greatness with the results of the first attempt relative to each sport.  
As I became more intent in subsequent attempts,  my desire to improve the results had shifted me away from my naturally developed skills.
I realized that by not being trained as an professional Athlete, I did not have the concentration skills necessary to maintain the results and would consistently do much better by utilizing my naturally developed skills, rather then forcing myself to perform.

My thoughts are; in real experience we are always delivered both positive and negative feedback during any training or learning of an activity. The feedback doesn't always come from an instructor or authoritarian, feedback is always delivered from a variety of sources. The perception of a negative and/or positive outcome is then the cumulative magnitude of all sources of feedback. Veritasium, you mentioned about it being culture specific. It actually is, but in a subtle way. If we look carefully at how the "controlled" studies have been done, we can see that they are "western" oriented (especially the negative feedback part). That is, it is not that positive feedback is better; it is that in the so-called controlled studies, negative feedback has been "improperly" used (it is not actual "feedback" it is simply "negative").

I would love to see a study where they compare:
- positive feedback only vs
- negative feedback only (truly negative feedback, not the western oriented feedback) vs
- both

Positive feedback AND negative feedback are necessary. Positive feedback can be used to reinforce good things and negative feedback to reduce bad things.

PS. Totally true about the statistical aspect of your video.

IMHO there are two kinds of feedbacks. Negative: 1) you failed this time. 2) you are a failure. Positive: 2) you did well this time. 2) You are  a winner. It is very important if the feedback is about a particular performance or about the person in general. If it is about the person in general, negative will eventually lead to trauma and positive eventually to arrogance. If it is about a particular performance it still depends on the "undertone": negative can mean "you can/should do better next time" and positive can mean "keep it up" or "you just were lucky". I'm afraid that whole feedback thing is way, way more complex. Just my humble opinion.

My biggest issue with the comparison to the Israeli fighter school is that the military, particularly aviation, is so involved in incredibly high risk activity that to try to avoid negative feedback when someone does something wrong is inherently dangerous in its own right. When you botch a maneuver its not just technically wrong, it could be flat out dangerous.

Infantry have since the beginning of time received relentless grilling and negative feedback during their inception phase and yet we see this as normal given the nature of what they do. If you screw up barrel discipline while on the firing range you can kill people. Ask anyone who's been through a basic training and their version of positive feedback would be not being given negative feedback.

So really, all that is being discussed in this video to me is extremely unsatisfying because it feels so generalized, cherry picking examples to feed into a canned theme. Is it REALLY about positive feedback versus negative? All I saw was a light contrasting of statistics versus implied outcomes of a few examples.

When you examine particularly driven individuals, those who usually perform at the very top of their field, you find them adoring accolades but also being constantly driven by the competition and the threat of failure. Fighter pilots are amongst the most notable of this breed of individual. They are not average, they are not normal, they are a cut above, extremely select individuals doing select duty. They're supposed to want to be there so giving them praise doesn't seem to be necessary to drive them to focus. In this sense I found that example to be a shallow interpretation based on the narrator being effectively ignorant of that example, mostly because he was interested in exploring a different more general thought.

For those who know nothing about combat aviation however, this probably all went over your head, which is why the example was used so carelessly in my opinion.

i dislike this video because:
When talking about which is better reward or punishment the core question is not wether or not a person or population on this particular day or week or month did better at some random task. the point of the debate is to determine which, reward or punishment, is more effective at making a person TRY harder and/or want to do better. i think we can all agree that for the vast majority, trying harder and wanting to do better almost always leads to better performance in the long term. all the examples given where over the duration of a 100 question test, a week of rugby, or a few days of flight training. this could all be post hoc. there needs to be a discussion of a long term experiment with controls and more than actual performance to determine efficacy (e.g. physiological markers, voluntary increase in studying/training, and other things that measure change in the persons determination) then and only then can we make any kind of determination that digs at the actual question, not these superficial observations. but we all know thorough human experiments like this are rare and difficult (sigh). all that being said i know for myself the more positive feed back i get the harder i want to try to continue to get positive feedback, but i know many others that see positive feed back as a rational for a break, which leads to reduced performance.

Having been a military pilot myself I would say there is a big difference between the average student and a military pilot candidate.  Primarily, that difference is motivation.  Those student pilots worked very hard to get to where they are.  If they were not already motivated to do well, they would not be there.  It is a competitive process from beginning to end.  They don't need to feel better about themselves to do better, they need constructive criticism to know what areas the need to work on.

Regression to the mean makes it so easy to come to the wrong conclusion. Unfortunately, being misled happens much more often, and in important venues, than you'd ever believe. Even many scientists come up with false conclusions fairly routinely. There's an unsettling article in the 22 November 2013 issue of the journal Science (Vol. 342 no. 6161 pp. 922-925 ), "When Mice Mislead", that reveals how the extremely common use of mice in drug studies, toxicology, etc. leads very often to false conclusions. It left me pretty concerned, actually. Have you given any thought to future episodes along the lines of "How We Know What Isn't So", superstition, the influence of bias; the many ways, such as this Regression to the Mean topic, that we are misled because we don't really appreciate how the scientific method should be best practised (more on the professional level), how to deal with random events and statistics (more on the layman level), and how psychological (or political!) bias can cloud the whole issue?

Sorry, but I have to correct a mistake made in this video, and it is a common mistake to make: "reward" and "positive feedback" are not interchangeable phrases, and neither is "punishment" and "negative feedback." Positive feedback is when stimuli is introduced, negative feedback is when stimuli is removed. The stimuli can be either pleasant or unpleasant. Veritasium, while regression to the mean probably has some real truth to it in the abstract, I can offer another theory as to why the Israeli pilots have a different outcome in negative reinforcement than with many other human skill training. The focus is more on WHAT is being trained, and the what the consequences of the outcome of said training. The example you gave is a military combat training exercise. The outcome of failure in these scenarios could result in the death himself or the death of an ally. Negative reinforcement can do a far better job to help motivate a recruit to train harder and to treat the next exercise with a more serious attitude. Positive reinforcement can cause complacency in the military, which is why it is not used as often. Complacency kills in wartime.

Also, the "culture" side of it I think has far more to do with it as well. In military culture, negative reinforcement goes far beyond negetive marks on a report. Usually negative physical, mental, and emotional reinforcement is used. This goes far beyond anything you typically see in the everyday world. Because this activity is permitted in this environment, military members have a far better incentive to perform well every time they train because of the very immediate and very real consequences the face if they fail.

Before writing this response I rewatched the video 3 times. I want to be as concise as possible because I think it might be real easy to either be super vague or imprecise about the progression of logic I'm trying to put forth. 
First let me begin with a variation on your basic premise.
Instead of Punishment or Reward, what about Investment, Punishment or Reward?
I add investment because it changes the locus from external validation to internal. You as an individual invest in yourself for your own benefit (regardless of outside verification. positive or negative)
You mention the idea of cultural bias possibly skewing the results, I agree. My expectation is that pilots in general are taught massively intricate details about how and why planes do what they do so that under abnormal circumstances pilots can improvise appropriate solutions (or execute maneuvers with precision).
Perhaps that difference in learning environment leads pilots to invest more time in being better where other test subjects might not have such stringent standards for progress.
For instance 100 test subjects sitting in a classroom taking a math test wouldn't be worried about dying if they failed the test or didn't pay as much attention.
It would seem pre-existent yet continuing standards for failure might compel fighter pilots to focus more towards self betterment having received a negative response (possibly because it serves as a direct reminder of what can happen if they fail when it truly counts).
I know this might sound weird but bear with me. The definition of the word Sin is to know the right way to do something but to choose to follow your own path anyway. It implies a sense of education to know what is right (and yet not do it anyway). I'm not religious but it seems like an appropriate concept for this situation.
If regression to the mean implies random responses to a series of questions (or in the case of fighter pilots a series of situation based conditions) then by the standards which pilots are trained regression to the mean wouldn't apply.
I believe fighter pilots are trained to perform physically with a complete set of information to work with and thus to fail a maneuver would be a Sin. The point to their training is to not make random decisions under any circumstances.
If their failure was caused by something outside of their ability to account for physically/logically then perhaps that shouldn't be a part of the statistical assessment (or at least accounted for as an anomaly or subset).
Long story made short the difference in the value/need for learning/experience might also skew the results.
I'm kinda curious if investment might not change the average participants commitment to the testing process.
For instance if you took the same one hundred students (this time in an accounting class so still math) and told them that their ability to parse out results in a coherent manner leads to a direct increase in the amount of money they will make for the rest of their lives. How much would it skew the test results. Would more students pay more attention or would outside factors such as overall goals per student (for instance accounting not having anything to do with their major)  keep them focused on other things?

Without find a way to account for these variables identifying multiple test groups becomes way more problematic. I believe you need more than just a control group but a means to identify the mental frame of reference of all test subjects in relation to their investment towards the outcome of the test presented.
Trick is balancing praise and wellbeing with punishment and the want for self improvement

I believe the behavior being modified determines the relative effectiveness of punishment vs reward.  Punishment is better for changing a specific behavior because it creates a salience point.  However, punishment can act as a distraction if used for general behavior.  Reward changes raises self-efficacy and positively changes general behavior, but doesn't create salience for specific behaviors.

In operant conditioning, negative reinforcement is not the same as punishment. Negative reinforcement is encouraging a behavior by avoiding a negative stimulus, like brushing your teeth to avoid a cavity. Punishment is intended to prevent a behavior, like spanking a child who was throwing a tantrum.

source for more info: http://psychology.about.com/od/operantconditioning/f/negative-reinforcement.htm

Punishment- def.= any stimuli given to a subject that "DECREASES" the likelihood of a behavior.

Reward- def.= any stimuli given to a subject that "INCREASES" the likelihood of a behavior.

This was very well done. Even as a psych major there was some thought-provoking stuff in here, and it was presented in a very accessible way. It's nice to see more stuff from this channel, it's surprisingly effective at educating on difficult subjects.

Regarding the subject though, it was never made clear that the pilot instructors were actively selecting the good pilots to praise and the bad pilots to reprimand. I assume this is the case given what I know about reward and punishment, but that detail is important.

If the instructors took a sample of 100 pilots and gave positive feedback to all of them (for whatever things they did well) you wouldn't expect a net decrease in their performance. The ones who did well would decrease and the ones who did poorly would increase toward the mean. The same would be true for the punishment group.

This would only occur if the instructors selected the good pilots to reward and the bad pilots to reprimand.

I actually read about this in a different book: The Drunkard's Walk: How Randomness Rules Our Live by Leonard Mlodinow.

Though he makes the point that positive and negative reinforcement don't effect individual attempts as much as random chance. But they do effect the average skill of the person.

So lets use the case of basketball. If you had a player with a 80% chance of making a free throw, obviously negative reinforcement after a missed throw would appear to work better, because the player had an 80% chance to make the basket already. But to increase your shooter's average over 80%, positive reinforcement works better.

I was told, by many psychology professors, that punishment is very effective at promoting or deterring behavior, it's actually too effective. However, negative reinforcement and positive reinforcement are usually better at keeping the desired behavior more habitual. When using a punishment paradigm you risk the chance the undesired behavior comes back when the punishment is no longer present. It's true to positive and negative reinforcement, I believe they call it extinction, but it isn't as detrimental as punishment.

Just to clarify, negative reinforcement is not punishment. It is escaping a stimulus that is aversive, which ends up becoming a behavior. Ex. Some people put their seat belt on because they don't want to hear the sound of the seat bell alarm. They are trying to escape that stimulus but aren't being punished by it. Punishment is a stimulus given after a behavior that's meant to be aversive but isn't present before the the behavior.

One thing that could also influence the effectiveness of of positive/negative feedback is the personality of the people involved.

For example, fighter pilots tend to be super alpha males with big chips on their shoulders.  Positive reinforcement may not have much effect on them as they already view themselves in a very positive light.  Getting them to change via smacking them down a peg or two may in fact be what works better.

I disagree with your blind application of statistics. 
Negative feedback draws attention to error; but positive feedback just points to things people already know well. 
Constant negative feedback however undermines effort, but so does positive feedback -because it does not encourage critique. 

In the case of the fighter pilot, negative feedback causes the pilot to focus on what he has done wrong - which is essential when you are in a multi-million dollar, difficult to use piece of equipment. Telling them what they did well does not offer this incentive. 

In the event of a school environment there is not as stringent a requirement on success. Students scoring poorly tend to have no put in as much effort as students which score highly. By providing negative feedback, you tell them what they are doing wrong; but you also discourage them, which results in a cyclic behavior - they don't want to study because they don't like the subject, so they don't study and do poorly which makes them hate the subject more. Vice versa, the positive feedback encourages more effort which nets more positive feedback from scores. 

Were statistics true, if you took a bunch of 4.00 students and gave them a test in what they were good at, you would see some students do poorly for no reason at all; but this does not happen. Otherwise certification would be meaningless.

"Pain is an effective teacher, but nobody wants to go to his classes"

People will work harder to avoid pain or negativity in the short term, but in the longer term, they will develop coping strategies such as blame shifting, avoidance,  and excuse making to explain poor behaviour.

Furthermore, it has been shown that actual reward (such as money) works primarily for repetitive, or non intellectual tasks, whereas emotional reward in the sense of personal satisfaction or accomplishment is more effective for intellectual or problem solving tasks.

The individual psyche of the participants must also be factored in.

So, whilst regression to the mean is a noteworthy mathematical concept to consider, there are of course, important psychological factors that produce great changes in performance.

My brain really dislikes statistics for a simple reason:

Any metaphor based in our human lives used to explain probability (flipping a coin, etc.) isn't actually probabilistic...

Likewise, anything that is truly probabilistic (like a theoretically probabilistic model) just loses meaning. What is probability, really? what is it that inherently makes something more "likely" to occurr? It's impossibly hard to truly grasp in its purest terms!

The worst part is that we don't know if things like wavefunction collapses are actually probabilistic in practice (which would make them good examples) or if we just don't understand them well enough.

Something that must be considered is the type of feedback received and what is praised. To give positive feed back to a student you could say "You did well, you must have studied really hard" praises them for studying which lead to good results. Alternatively you could say "You did well, you must be really smart" which praises natural ability and not the effort. Students praised for effort likely will continues that effort to receive future praise when students praised for natural ability are less likely to study as they received no reward directly for doing so resulting a drop in test scores.

The same is true for negative feedback. You can tell someone "You really suck at this" or you can say "You're doing these things wrong" What the feedback is focused on can give different results.

The difference between Regression to the Mean and the Gambler's Fallacy is sample size. In GF, it's only one random event, so the probability isn't changed between the past and present. But in RM, it's a collection of random events. So while one event isn't dependent on it's past, it IS dependent on the average performance of the present, because the probability will be that it is in the middle, regardless of where it was before.

I would like to point out that there is a difference between negative feedback, positive feedback, and punishment when it comes to motor learning (which is mostly you cover in the video).

Punishment involves adding something that the learner does not want (insults, push ups, etc).

Negative feedback involves taking away something they do not want (if you win the game, you don't have to come to training next week).

Positive feedback involves adding something the learner wants (if you win the game, you get pizza).

In the years I worked in Q.C. and needed to give people feedback about their work and try to work out methods of improving quality I found that a positive feedback will improve a lot of things.
Sometimes there is the need to give a negative feedback to someone who did something wrong for a significant time but if you give people a positive feedback and try to encourage them on their work they are more likely to inquire about the way they execute their work and they stop to see you as an enemy :)
This way quality improves and the relations within the department are strengthened.
This won't work for everyone and some people see it as a weakness to be nice but it really works the statistics that were made in our department showed a big improvement in the general morale and quality of work of the department. 

Most of the time I just went directly to the person who did something the wrong way or where you could see a tendency of his work getting worse and spoke to them about the things they did well at first and gave them some hints or asked about why they made somethings that way. Never saying it was wrong but telling them that it was usually made in a different way. This way they didn't lose their face in front of others and appreciated my feedback.

The downside is that you will end up being under appreciated because you cannot make a fuzz about your work but generally because you start to develop a positive attitude to your coworkers and your job you will begin to feel a lot better (^-^)

As a parent of an autistic child, I struggled with this scenario and could have used this knowledge decades ago when she was young.
Being a communications disease with many a spectrum under it's umbrella, autism tests the parent's ability to dole out any lessons in cause and effect to the more severe of it's victims. I went from both ends of the range on positive and negative reinforcement over the years attempting to teach my daughter some sort of social cohesiveness- at no point, or at any time in all those years (she is now grown and struggling as an adult) did I ever feel as if either option offered any progress.
I came to the conclusion that ultimately, negative reinforcement is far more draining, exhaustive, and generally debilitating to all parties involved, and especially to those souls who live and are part of the fringe and outer circles of that relationship. Negativity breeds a dark environment where at the very least, positivity shines a little light on an otherwise cumbersome day.

I think you're sort of skating around the actual statistical process here to just speak to your point; regardless, I feel like expounding on some statistics.  When you have a group you need to consider the variation of the group, say, it's confidence intervals.  In statistics you compare two groups using a t-test, a test which compares the variance of the groups as well as it's means.  If these groups overlap enough then the groups are considered to be statistically similar.  So in the fighter pilot test, one maneuver isn't enough to represent the mean performance (your regression to the mean).  If the pilot does 100 maneuvers, then you know what his actual mean performance would be, and then could judge his follow up performances.  If he performs the maneuver again (after more training or berating) you'll have statistical evidence to determine if indeed his new maneuver is statistically significantly different from his old performance.
